Award.AwardTitle: Stratospheric and Tropical Influences on the Mid-Latitude Circulation Response to Rising Greenhouse Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to understand how increases in global-mean temperature due to rising greenhouse gas concentrations will affect the jet stream and storm tracks (the typical paths of midlatitude frontal systems) found in the midlatitudes of the Northern and Southern Hemisphere. Previous studies of global warming simulations have found that jet streams and storm tracks in both hemispheres shift towards their respective poles with rising temperature, but the dynamical mechanisms for the shifts are not well understood. Moreover, simulations from different models do not agree as to the magnitude of the shifts. One issue addressed in this project is the role of stratospheric dynamics in producing the shifts (particularly in the Northern Hemisphere), and the extent to which enhanced representation of the stratosphere (more levels in the stratosphere on the model computational grid, for instance) leads to qualitative differences in the shifts. A second issue addressed is the extent to which the jet and storm track shifts in the Southern Hemisphere are influenced by tropical processes.

The broader impacts of the work come from the practical value of an improved understanding of the atmospheric circulation response to greenhouse gas-induced warming. Shifts in the jet streams and storm tracks can affect regional climate in the midlatitude, and poleward shifts may lead to widening of the dry subtropical subsidence belts. The project also seeks to understand differences in circulation change from different models, and may help to reduce uncertainty in projections of future climate change. In addition, the work will support and train a graduate student, thereby providing for the future work force in this area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This purpose of this project was to improve our understanding of future predicted mid-latitude circulation change and the factors contributing to its uncertainties in both the Northern Hemisphere (NH) and the Southern Hemisphere (SH).

 

The primary focus of past research on mid-latitude circulation change has been on the zonal mean poleward shifting of the mid-latitude westerlies that typically accompanies increasing greenhouse gases in model simulations. Research under this award demonstrated that there is considerable regional and seasonal variation in the circulation response to increasing greenhouse gases (GHGs) and that the poleward shifting view of the circulation is not a good description locally of circulation changes in the NH wintertime where there is a dominant role for changes in the stationary waves.

 

This analysis then motivated an improved understanding of the stationary wave responses to increasing GHGs. Two main features of regional circulation change in the NH were identified as being of particular importance for regional hydroclimate change: a wave train pattern over North America that contributes to wetting of the US west coast and drying in the interior southwest and a high pressure anomaly centered over the Mediterranean that contributes to drying in that region. While models rather robustly predict the occurrence of these features, they differ in the magnitude of these responses. Research then focused on obtaining an improved understanding of the mechanisms behind these features with an aim to also understand the reasons behind the spread in modeled responses.

 

For the North American circulation response, a close link between the magnitude of the wave train response and regional hydroclimate change was demonstrated and the mechanism behind this wave train response was then proposed. Using an idealized stationary wave model, it was demonstrated that the North American wave train response was produced in response to the strengthening of the westerlies in the sub-tropical upper troposphere that accompanies the warming of the tropical upper troposphere. A further theoretical understanding of this response was then provided using stationary wave theory. Climatologically, stationary waves of intermediate scale (zonal wavenumbers 4 to 7) exist in the Pacific and are guided toward North America by the Pacific jet stream. Stationary wave theory tells us that the length scale of these stationary waves depends on the magnitude and structure of the Pacific jet stream. When the westerlies of the Pacific jet stream increase in strength as the planet warms, the length scale of the stationary waves that can be supported by the atmosphere increases. The result is an altered structure of the wave train on the eastern edge of the Pacific jet stream over North America. Linking this circulation response to a rather robust feature of global warming (the warming of the tropical upper troposphere and the associated strengthening of the upper tropospheric Pacific westerlies) gives us confidence that this is a response that we should expect to see in the future. However, it was demonstrated that the magnitude of this response in a given model was closely connected to the amplitude of the present day climatological stationary waves in that model and that the majority of models have stationary wave amplitudes in their present day climate that are too large. As such, they are likely over-predicting the magnitude of this response and its associated hydroclimate changes.

 

For the Mediterranean circulation response, research focused on understanding the role of local topography in generating that response. While it was found that the topography of the Middle-East and the Atlas Mountains of North Africa do not play an important role in the future circulation change, this analysis led to a demonstration of the importance of Middle-Eastern topography for the present day summertime climate of the Mediterranean.

 

Another factor of relevance for inter-model spread in the Northern Hemisphere circulation response to increasing GHGs in the NH wintertime is the influence of changes in the stratospheric polar vortex. Model experiments were performed that demonstrated the downward influence of uncertainty in the stratospheric vortex response on the troposphere below and quantified its impacts. Uncertainty in the stratospheric polar vortex response to climate change was shown to contribute to uncertainty in sea level pressure over the Arctic, the response of the Atlantic jet stream and the response of precipitation over Europe and the Mediterranean.

 

For the SH, research under this grant demonstrated that previous theories for the reason behind model spread in the jet stream response to increasing GHGs that were determined using the annual mean are inadequate when it comes to explaining seasonal variations. This motivates future work to improve our understanding in this regard.

 

This award supported the training of two postdoctoral fellows.
